title-group.article-title: Effect of Various Hallux Valgus Reconstruction on Sesamoid Location
title-group.subtitle: A Radiographic Study

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The correction of sesamoid subluxation is an important component of hallux valgus reconstruction with some surgeons feeling that the sesamoids can be pulled back under the first metatarsal head when imbricating the medial capsule during surgery. The purpose of this study was to radiographically assess the effect of an osteotomy on sesamoid location relative to the second metatarsal.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: This is a retrospective radiographic study review of 165 patients with hallux valgus treated with reconstructive osteotomies. Patients were included if they underwent a scarf or basilar osteotomy for hallux valgus but were excluded if they had inflammatory arthropathy or lesser metatarsal osteotomy. A modified McBride soft tissue procedure was performed in conjunction with the basilar and scarf osteotomies. Each patient’s preoperative and postoperative radiographs were evaluated for hallux valgus angle, intermetatarsal 1-2 angle, tibial sesamoid classification, and lateral sesamoid location relative to the second metatarsal.

sec.title: Result:
sec.p: The greatest correction of both hallux valgus and intermetatrsal 1-2 angle was achieved in basilar osteotomies (20.6 degrees and 9.7 degrees, respectively), then scarf osteotomies (14.4 degrees and 8.7 degrees, respectively). Basilar and scarf osteotomies both corrected medial sesamoid subluxation relative to the first metatarsal head an average of 2-3 classification stages. All osteotomies had minimal lateral sesamoid location change relative to the second metatarsal.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The majority of sesamoid correction correlated with the intermetatarsal 1-2 correction. The concept that medial capsular plication pulls the sesamoids beneath the first metatarsal (ie, changes the location of the sesamoids relative to the second metatarsal) was not supported by our results.

sec.title: Level of Evidence:
sec.p: Level III, retrospective case series.

body.p: Hallux valgus is one of the most common chronic foot complaints, with a prevalence of over 23% in adults and up to 35.7% in the elderly.17 The majority of procedures for hallux valgus reconstruction use a combination of a soft tissue procedure and an osteotomy.1-10,12-16,19,20 When osteotomies are performed, the first metatarsal changes its relative position not only to the second metatarsal but also to the sesamoids.16 The correction of sesamoid subluxation is an important component of hallux valgus reconstruction to remove the dynamic deforming force of the flexor hallux brevis muscles. Failure to correct sesamoid subluxation can lead to recurrence of hallux valgus, sesamoid overload/irritation, and altered walking mechanics.

While it is generally accepted that medial capsular placation is a necessary component of bunion surgery to aid in hallux valgus angular correction, the effect of soft tissue balancing and osteotomy correction on sesamoid position remains unclear. Some authors have described tightening of the medial capsular tissues as pulling the sesamoid sling back beneath the metatarsal head and maintaining the sesamoid reduction.5,10,14 If this were the case, then the position of the lateral sesamoid should move away from the second metatarsal postoperatively. We hypothesized that the realignment of the sesamoids occurred due to the osteotomy repositioning the metatarsal over the sesamoids, and, thus, the position of the sesamoid relative to the second metatarsal would be unchanged. The purpose of this study was to radiographically compare the effects of various osteotomies with a distal soft tissue reconstruction with a particular focus on sesamoid location.

sec.title: Methods and Materials
sec.p: A retrospective radiographic review was undertaken of all first metatarsal osteotomies performed at a single institution by 2 senior surgeons (DBT and TPC) for hallux valgus deformity from January 2006 to December 2010. In sum, 317 patients underwent first metatarsal osteotomies for hallux valgus reconstruction from 2006 to 2010. Patients were excluded if they had a chevron osteotomy without a distal soft tissue reconstruction (modified McBride procedure), revision hallux valgus correction, history of inflammatory disease (ie, rheumatoid disease), incomplete radiographic follow-up, or more than 1 lesser metatarsal osteotomy. Demographic data were reviewed for the remaining 101 patients (10 male, 91 female), with an average age of 52 years (range, 15-89) and a follow-up of 7 months (range, 0.5-56) (Table 1).

sec.title: Radiographic Measurements
sec.p: All radiographic measurements were made by a surgeon not involved in the care of the patients at the final follow-up radiographs (EHH).

sec.title: Hallux Valgus Deformity
sec.p: Hallux valgus angle was determined by measuring the angle created by connecting the centers of the metatarsal head to the proximal metatarsal articular surface with a similar line made on the proximal phalanx. The center of the proximal articular surface was defined as the midpoint between the medial and lateral edges. The intermetatarsal 1-2 angle was determined in the same fashion by connecting the lines created from using the same method on the first and second metatarsals (Figure 1).

caption.p: Measurement of intermetatarsal 1-2 and hallux valgus angle.

sec.title: Sesamoid Positioning
sec.p: Medial sesamoid subluxation was graded by percentage overlap of sesamoid over first metatarsal reference line (Figure 2). The reference line bisected the first metatarsal along its long axis.

list-item.p: Grade 0: no overlap with sesamoid medial to line
Grade 3: no overlap with sesamoid lateral to line

sec.p: Lateral sesamoid location was evaluated by measuring the perpendicular distance from the second metatarsal shaft (Figure 3). Each measurement was then normalized by the length of the second metatarsal to eliminate magnification error. The percentage correction was determined as a ratio between preoperative and postoperative measurements to reduce variability between the size of the feet.

sec.title: Surgical Technique
sec.p: A modified McBride release was performed in conjunction with the scarf and basilar osteotomy. A dorsal first webspace approach was utilized for a complete release of the adductor and intermetatarsal ligament from the lateral aspect of the lateral sesamoid, followed by a longitudinal capsulotomy dorsal to the sesamoid to further mobilize the sesamoid sling. An L capsulotomy was performed through a straight skin incision centered over the medial eminence. The capsulotomy was plicated at the time of capsular closure to help maintain alignment.

A scarf osteotomy was performed though a medial approach to the midshaft of the first metatarsal, dividing the abductor muscle and elevating the periosteum. The first metatarsal was osteotomized in a Z-shape, proximal to the articular cartilage. The osteotomy was laterally shifted/rotated and stabilized with 3 bicortical screws.

A basilar osteotomy was performed though a proximal dorsal approach to the first metatarsal. A closing wedge osteotomy was made and fixated with a 6-hole 2.4-mm T-plate (Synthes, Paoli, Pennsylvania) with 3 nonlocking screws through the plate on either side of the osteotomy.

sec.title: Postoperative Care
sec.p: Patients were placed in a bunion wrap at the time of surgery. Partial heel weightbearing in a postoperative shoe was allowed for the first week after surgery and foot-flat weightbearing to tolerance for weeks 2-6. Patients were advanced to regular shoe wear at that time.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: A paired t test was employed to evaluate the difference between measurements taken preoperatively and postoperatively with P values less than .05 defined as significant.

sec.title: Osteotomy Correction
sec.p: The hallux valgus angle correction achieved by scarf and basilar osteotomy was, respectively, 14.4 degrees ± 6.6 degrees and 20.6 degrees ± 9.4 degrees, while the intermetatarsal 1-2 angle correction was 8.7 degrees ± 3.1 degrees and 9.7 degrees ± 4.4 degrees (Table 2).

sec.title: Medial Sesamoid Subluxation
sec.p: Because medial sesamoid subluxation values are reported in digital tiers of subluxation, the data were best analyzed by population. Preoperative subluxation in the basilar osteotomy group was primarily grade 3 (68.7%), while the scarf osteotomy group was primarily grade 2 (61.1% ) Both osteotomy groups corrected on average 2 grades (scarf = 50%, basilar = 47%), resulting in an postoperative grade 0 subluxation (scarf = 88.9%, basilar = 36.1%). The scarf and basilar osteotomy groups were frequently able to achieve a 3-grade correction (scarf = 16.7%, basilar = 21.7%) (Table 3).

fn.p: The amount of correction achieved by each osteotomy. Data are represented in terms of percentage of patients able to achieve each grade of correction. Both osteotomies frequently achieved 2 grades of correction, while basilar osteotomies most frequently achieved 3 grades of correction.

sec.title: Lateral Sesamoid Location
sec.p: The lateral sesamoid position was evaluated both by a millimeter measurement from the second metatarsal and as a normalized correction relative to the second metatarsal shaft (Table 4). Although the basilar osteotomies provided a statistically significant correction, the magnitude of correction was minimal for both absolute and relative measurements.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The importance of soft tissue balancing, radiographically reflected by the sesamoid position, has been described by Mann as a cornerstone to correction of the hallux valgus deformity. Soft tissue balancing—with release of the adductor hallucis and transverse metatarsal ligament—and longitudinally releasing the lateral sesamoid, has been described by some to permit the sesamoids to be reduced beneath the metatarsal head with plication of the medial capsule.10,12,14

In a radiographic review of 118 feet, Saragas and Becker found that the distance between the sesamoids and the second metatarsal did not differ between hallux valgus and normal feet.18 This study implies that the pathoanatomy of hallux valgus involves the first metatarsal head deviating away from the sesamoids, while they remain in a constant position relative to the second metatarsal. Our study has conversely found that the lateral sesamoid position similarly does not change relative to the second metatarsal when the hallux valgus deformity is corrected surgically. Our finding emphasizes the importance of achieving proper bony alignment during surgery, as one cannot expect the capsular repair to further correct sesamoid position. While not a component of this study, the 2 senior authors anecdotally have found that intraoperative fluoroscopy before and after capsular closure does not lead to an appreciable change in sesamoid position.

While not a subject of this study, we do believe that the distal soft tissue release (ie, modified McBride procedure) is an important part of the procedure. It is likely that some patients have a contracture of the lateral capsule along the dorsal aspect of the lateral sesamoid, which would prevent the sesamoids from being able to reduce beneath the first metatarsal head if it were not released. However, it is unlikely that release of the intermetatarsal ligament between the lateral sesamoid and second metatarsal helps with the reduction of the sesamoids. Lin et al found that release of the intermetatarsal ligament was not necessary for lateral release in a modified McBride procedure but that its release does ensure that the adductor tendon was completely released from the lateral sesamoid.11

With regard to the differences in the scarf and basilar osteotomies, one surgeon (DBT) only used a basilar osteotomy for greater intermetatarsal 1-2 deformities, and the other (TPC) utilized both a scarf and basilar osteotomy, with his use of the scarf becoming less common later in the study period. While the number of scarf osteotomies was low, we decided to include them in the analysis, as it has become a very popular method of hallux valgus correction in some centers.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, we found no significant change in lateral sesamoid position relative to the second metatarsal after bunion surgery. Thus, its reduction beneath the first metatarsal is due to bony realignment of the first metatarsal back over the sesamoids. We believe that it is important to confirm appropriate sesamoid correction intraoperatively before medial capsular closure. We did find consistent improvement in the hallux valgus and intermetatarsal 1-2 angles following surgery.
